conversation.bResponse: Yes, you may need a visa to study in Romania depending on your citizenship and whether or not you have completed your studies. Citizens of the European Union, European Economic Area, and the Swiss Confederation, as well as their family members and beneficiaries of an international protection, can have their study papers evaluated and recognized by the Romanian Ministry of Education's National Center for Diploma Recognition and Equivalence (CNRED) for further studies or access to the Romanian labor market without needing a visa. However, individuals from non-EU countries might require a visa to study in Romania, especially if they haven't completed their studies or don't have equivalent documentation recognized by CNRED. For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/education

conversation.aPrompt: Are there any specific national or religious holidays that affect school calendars?
conversation.bResponse:
Yes, there are several national and religious holidays that may affect the school calendar in Romania. Some examples include:
1. Christmas (Crăciun): December 24th and 25th - schools will be closed on these two days.
2. New Year's Day (Noul An): January 1st - schools will be closed on this day.
3. Easter (Paști) & Good Friday (Miercuri înainte de Paști): April 6th & April 7th - schools will be closed on these two days if they fall during the week.
4. Labour Day (Ziua Muncii): May 1st - schools will be closed on this day.
5. Independence Day (Sfârşitul Războiului Fecioarei Maria): August 15th - schools will be closed on this day.
Please note that additional local holidays might exist depending on the region and community. For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/education
